author: Hallie R.

description: Lunch was great. Vegitarian plate and a lentil/rice side order. Fresh ingredients, great flavors, fast, friendly service (family operation?), good portions, great value. I've taken dishes from here to potluck parties in the past with foodie friends, and everyone commented on how good the food was.
author: Miguel L.

description: This falafel will not make you feel awful. Quickly prepared, fresh, and flavorful, there is something for everyone at Taboun. I've had just about everything on the menu and have never been disappointed (minus the time I took too long to eat my deluxe falafel wrap, only to find it had become soggy).  The business owner proudly displays thank you notes from local non-profits to whom s/he has donated. Worth it on all fronts.
author: J A.

description:
yum, yum, yum.  chicken shwarma with hummus, extra pickles (don't ask me why it's good cuz it just is) and tons of spicy sauce or the veggie plate for this hulagirl, please.

thank god i work at home and can partake of the deliciousness for lunch at least once a week...
author: nic f.

description:
Update - 2/2011:

Note to Taboun's management: if I find a piece of a blue, cut rubber band in my baba ghanoush, and I bring it to your attention, the response I'm expecting is (1) an apology and (2) a full refund.  Telling me that I'd already eaten it doesn't make up for the fact that you may have poisoned me.  Never again.


*******************************



In an ideal world, I'd give Taboun 3.5 stars.  But life's not perfect and Yelp doesn't give me the option of 3.5 stars.  So I'm giving Taboun 3 stars today, with the hopes that my next meal at Taboun won't be as disappointing as my last. 

In Taboun's defense, I have always ordered the vegetarian combo plate and have been mostly happy with it: large portions of (usually) fresh cucumber salad, along with hummus & baba ghanoush & plenty of pita bread -- (mostly) good food, and enough to share.

So that made my most recent meal at Taboun that much more disappointing.  I decided to be adventurous and try something different: the falafel deluxe wrap, "plated."  I understood my order to mean (1) deluxe = some of that yummy grilled eggplant sitting on the counter along with "potatoes," and (2) 2 yummy side dishes and some pita bread.  I was sorely disappointed.  Although the falafel itself was fine, it was pretty cold, temperature-wise.  My kid loved it, though, and it was coated in tahini, so I figured that was fine.  But there were way too many raw onions inside the wrap.  Also, there was maybe just a piece or two of that tasty-looking eggplant and instead of "potatoes," there were two mediocre french fries in my wrap.  I'm sorry, but if your menu HAS "good ol' fashioned [french] fries" on it, why would you say that you're adding "potatoes" when, in fact, you're really just adding two soggy french fries?  Seems like false advertising to me.  Besides, my two yummy side dishes turned out to be weak in comparison with the veggie plate: if I order a side of french fries, could you spare more than, say, six or eight?  That seemed kind of cheap.  The two dolmas were tasty, but the single piece of dry pita bread, cut into quarters, was missing something -- say, tahini?  And while you're at it, could you at least offer me some ketchup for my six or eight fries?

I'll probably go back to Taboun, if only because (1) this place is in our neighborhood and is near my kid's favorite park, (2) for $18, my spouse, toddler and I were full after our shared meal, and (3) the food is fast -- which is ideal for a family on the go.  But when we do go back to Taboun, I will never stray from the veggie plate again!  For better food, you'll pay more (an arm and a leg, perhaps) at La Mediterranee, but you won't ever be disappointed.
author: Susan L.

description: The owner of the corner grocery store at Parnassus & Stanyan opened up Taboun next door about a year+ ago.  He spent months and months overseeing the construction of the restaurant and did a great job given the small space.  It is clean, fresh, and interesting.  The walls are solid murals which were hand painted.  They are so perfect it is hard to believe they were hand painted, but I watched the painter for months.  The staff is all very friendly and accommodating too.  Now, as far as the food, it is also great.  Very authentic middle eastern.  The menu is nicely displayed above the counter, easy to decipher, and reasonably priced considering the portions.  Everything is very fresh too.  I highly recommend it.
author: Mikey S.

description: Whenever I'm in the area, I make sure to stop by Taboun for a falafel wrap.  Oh, my, they are just so tasty here!  I haven't gone beyond the falafel wrap on the menu yet but having read the other reviews here, I'm promising myself to venture there.  The place is very clean, nicely decorated, quiet and has very pleasant service people.
author: Debra M.

description: An oasis!  I was in the hood on Sunday afternoon, around 4:30 pm and starved due to not eating since breakfast very early that day.  I ordered the chicken shish kebab dinner, which was quite large by the way.  It comes with a lot of chicken, rice, and two sides.  I chose the mojdara (lentils and rice with onions, delish) and the yogurt salad.  So pleasantly surprised because it was not greasy, the chicken was actually moist, not dried out and extremely delcious.  My friend had beef and lamb shish kebab but as a wrap and it was huge.  It was actually two wraps.  She couldn't eat the whole thing in one sitting.  So, lunch and dinner for her, for the price of one meal.  Pretty cool.  I could've easily done the same but I was so hungry I ate it all.  The place was clean and the employees really nice and helpful.  I wish it were closer to my home, I'd be there all the time.
author: Magdalena ..

description: I just ate there yesterday with my pickiest friend and he actually loved it. It's very clean and efficient. All of the food was so refreshingly fresh that we were ordering some of our favorite sides to go while we were still eating our meal. Enough said.
author: Jennifer L.

description: One of my favorite tricks is to call ahead from the train and order a chicken shwarma with extra hot sauce. OOOOOeeee. That's some good shwarma.
author: Andrew H.

description: Best falafel: crisp, with a little kick.
author: yvette l.

description: Pretty damn good Middle Eastern food.  I'd give it 5 stars except that, despite how wonderful it is, I know a better place that's better, House of Falafel in Cupertino.  Taboun is just too damn Cole Valley yuppieville clean for me.  When I want cheap Middle Eastern food, I expect the smell to ooze out of the place, to be able to feel the heat of the stove as the chef works his magic.  That's just me though, I'm sure plenty of people love that fact that it's flawlessly clean.  I like that for nice sit down restaurants, but not cheapo falafel types.  House of Falafel is also cheaper too, but perhaps that's just SF being more expensive that anywhere else.  Foodwise, Taboun is solid and I'd recommend it over any other Middle Eastern food in the area.
author: William C.

description: Hummus so good, I'm convinced it has crack in it. Minus one star because every time I ask for my meal "plated," which is clearly an option on their menu, they look at me like I have 5 heads. Come on now-no lavash. Not so difficult.
author: Sara B.

description: This place is money.  I basically go every Sunday while my girlfriend is working the night shift at sf gen.  They give you huge portions for a cheap price.  Both chicken and lamb/beef shawirma are delicious and the veggie plate is unbeatable.  I love you taboun!
author: Chris E.

description: Chicken shawarma was pretty tasty, but it was a little heavy on the cucumbers. The dolma was great, though.
author: Ben S.

description: This is the best showarma in the city.  I have never had a bad meal there.  Nice people, great food, fast service.  Thats what it takes in SF!!
author: sfc j.

description:
Best Falafel sandwich around!

Get the deluxe....eggplant and potatoes added to just about anything.
author: Kevin A.

description: This place is casual and I generally get takeout from it about every other month.  Great chicken kebabs, tabouleh, hummus.  The dolmas are a bit too tangy for me.  The chicken kebab dinner is enough for 2 people so it's definitely a good deal.  The lamb dishes are good as well.
author: win c.

description: hmm i didnt know i liked mediterranean food, but i think i just don't like vegetarian mediterranean food (not a big fan of feta & falafel).  but once i started trying the meat dishes i was pleasantly surprised at how yummy they are.  This place wraps up their shwarma with cucumbers, onion and tomato like a burrito... order the chicken or lamb-beef wrap with hot sauce... yummmm.
author: tasha h.

description:
Wonderful, delightful authentic middle eastern dishes; all the usual offerings (but better) plus unusual main courses and sides that you don't often see outside of Germany or North Africa/Mideast. Seriously good options for vegetarians as well, as Eric M. notes.

Also the owner, who runs Sunny Country on the corner, and his family are wonderful people who are darling to the local kids.

All you folks visiting GGP, up at UCSF or hanging out in the area, Taboun is worth a visit.
author: caitlin c.

description: I'm Vegetarian, and often seek out Middle-Eastern restaurants for the tasty, Veggie-friendly fare.  I tried out Taboun on short notice earlier this week, as I was buying for a small group of people, for an informal gathering (and it's just around the corner from my apartment).  Rather than go the standard route of getting a wrap (a felafel or something else), I instead went with some sides; all very reasonably-priced, and very good-sized portions: A dozen felafels, a Mojadara (Lentils & Rice, cooked with onions) and Hummus.  I must say I was quite pleased with the quality.  The felafels were huge & tasty (they're quite often dry & flavorless from many Middle-Eastern restaurants), the Mojadara was lovely & filling (and again, a large portion), and the Hummus was EXCELLENT (much better than you would buy in your local grocery store.  It's funny, hummus - it's such a simple thing, but so easy to screw up!  It can easily be considered the measure of a Middle-Eastern restaurant - how well they do Hummus, as the care they put into this very simple dish will often indicate the level of quality you'll get from other dishes.  The Hummus at Taboun is great - wonderful balance of flavors: not too lemony, not too garlicky, with just the right amount of olive oil).  OK, so I didn't try too many items.  But the ones I DID try were all excellent, and I will take them as indicators for the quality of the rest of the menu.  I will definitely go back (in fact, I've been thinking about it all week, but haven't had the opportunity).  If you like Middle-Eastern/Mediterranean food (and live in the Cole Valley area), then Taboun is certainly worth a shot.
author: Eric H.

description: one of my usual neighborhood lunch haunts.  the chicken schwarma is really good, as is the falafel.  i used to always get it on the lavash, but lately i've converted to the plate.  and, bonus, they don't leave out the pickles when you get it on the plate.  just in case you were worried.  i admit, i was.  just a little.  and the falafel is good too.  they let you order one on the side for like a quarter or something.  i'm sure other things are good here too, but although i basically eat here once a week, i've never tried anything else.  the chicken's that good.
author: brian g.

description: how delicious are you?!  meats perfectly seasoned, tender and tasty as heck. the best hummus, hands down and falafel sent to you by a greek god. i have not eaten mediterranean food anywhere else in SF for the past 5 years because of this heavenly place. you have spoiled me, taboun.
author: Zeena B.

description: We often take out from there.  We like their menu a lot.  The restaurant itself is extremely casual and that is why you should think of it as a take-out place.
author: Miinno N.

description: I call in orders to Taboun a couple times a month.  The lamb/beef and chicken shawarmas are tasty and I love the baba ganoush (though it's been a little tangy at times).  The portions are generous.  I've never seen this place full, but they seem to have a constant flow of people coming in/out.  I prefer to call ahead...it can otherwise take a while to get your food.
author: Kristin F.
